questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought with complaints of severe abdominal pain.  He consumes a balanced diet and vaccination is up to date. Laboratory studies show a Hb of 9gm/dl and elevated serum lactate. USG abdomen shows a bull's eye sign. Which of the following tests will help ascertain the potential etiology of his underlying condition?
questions.solution:
An acute abdomen with a bull's eye lesion on USG is likely to be an intussusception in this patient's age group. This patient's Hemoglobin is reduced, despite consuming an adequate diet indicating a nondietary cause of anemia. Meckel's diverticulum could be a likely cause of his anemia and a potential cause of the intussusception and should be evaluated for with a radionuclide pertechnetate scan. 

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the bowel is telescoped into an adjacent segment. Patients present with cramping abdominal pain, palpable sausage-shaped abdominal mass, and passage of red currant jelly stools. Vomiting may not begin later and with time, may be bile-stained. 

Meckel's diverticulum is a portion of the vitelline duct that persists as an outpouching of the ileum. The diverticulum is usually asymptomatic unless it contains heterotopic pancreatic or gastric mucosa, which may lead to bleeding, ulceration, or perforation. Usually, the bleeding goes unnoticed and only comes to light on routine exams which shows anemia and is evaluated further. A Technitium 99 pertechnetate scan is used for the evaluation of Meckels diverticulum. 

Intussusception is one of the common causes of intestinal obstruction in a paediatric patient. Ileo-colic junction is the most common site of involvement. The condition may arise due to the presence of lead points as seen in enlarged submucosal Payer's patch, Meckel's diverticulum ,intestinal polyp, inflamed appendix, submucosal hemorrhage seen in Henoch-Schonlein purpura, and intestinal duplication cysts.

Diagnosis is confirmed by abdominal ultrasound which shows the pathognomonic target sign/bull's eye sign (shown below). 

Treatment of intussusception includes hydrostatic reduction by enema using contrast material or air. Surgical reduction is only done in the presence of refractory shock, suspected bowel necrosis or perforation, peritonitis, and multiple recurrences after hydrostatic reduction. 

Other options:

Option B: CT angiography can be used to diagnose a cause of GI bleeds, but is usually less sensitive for Meckels diverticulum. 

Option C: Serum WBC counts are a non-specific test but can be helpful in diagnosing appendicitis. But this child's bull's eye lesion makes a diagnosis of intussusception more likely.

Option D: Increased serum lead levels can cause abdominal colic, however, it is not a cause of intussusception, and thus is not useful in this patient.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of sudden onset central abdominal pain, fever, vomiting, and several episodes of bloody diarrhea. He has a past history of hypertension. After a detailed workup, he was diagnosed with acute mesenteric ischemia. Which of the following tests should be done further in this patient to evaluate the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with acute abdominal pain secondary to acute mesenteric ischemia(AMI). An arterial embolic clot is the most common cause of AMI and the most common source of this clot is the left atrium/ventricle due to atrial fibrillation. Thus a 2D echo must be done in this patient to check for clots in the heart as they need to be treated soon to prevent a stroke. 

Mesenteric ischemia may be acute or chronic. The superior mesenteric artery (SMA) is most likely affected. An embolus is the most common cause of SMA occlusion. Possible sources for SMA emboisation include:

  • Left atrium in atrial fibrillation
  • The left ventricle after mural myocardial infarction
  • Vegetations on mitral and aortic valves associated with endocarditis and
  • An atheromatous plaque from an aortic aneurysm.

Other causes of mesenteric ischemia include:

  • Atherosclerosis of mesenteric vessels
  • Vasculitides
  • Venous thrombosis in factor V Leiden mutation
  • Non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia due to alterations in splanchnic blood flow.

The most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia is the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis. The pain is typically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings.

Associated clinical features include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal distension, peritonitis, and the passage of bloody stools.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia is angiography, and management is laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to resect the compromised bowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Doppler of the lower limbs is used to evaluate for deep vein thrombosis. However, a DVT causes pulmonary infarctions. Arterial thrombosis usually occurs due to an embolus originating in the left chamber of the heart. 

Option B: CT chest is not a sensitive test to evaluate for a clot in the heart chambers. 

Option D: ESR offers no diagnostic value in this patient.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female at 24 weeks gestation with obstetric score G4P1L0A2 presents with acute abdominal pain. An urgent CT scan is done and shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the CT scan showing a hypointensity in the spleen indicates a splenic infarction. The likely cause of infarction in this patient is thrombosis secondary to antiphospholipid syndrome (recurrent pregnancy losses).

Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoantibody-mediated acquired thrombophilia characterized by recurrent arterial or venous thrombosis and/or pregnancy morbidity. It primarily affects females. APS may either be primary or secondary to other autoimmune diseases, mainly SLE (secondary). The diagnosis of APS should be seriously considered in cases of thrombosis, cerebral vascular accidents in individuals <55 years of age, or pregnancy morbidity in the presence of livedo reticularis or thrombocytopenia. Laboratory criteria for APS include lupus anticoagulant (LA), anticardiolipin (aCL) antibody assay, and Aanti-β2GPI (glycoprotein 1) antibodies assay.

Clinical and Laboratory Criteria for Diagnosis of Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome:

Clinical criteria:

Obstetric

  • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks
  • One or more deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks
  • Severe pre-eclampsia necessitating delivery before 34 weeks
  • Vascular: One or more episodes of arterial, venous, or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organ.

Laboratory criteria:

  • Presence of lupus anticoagulant
  • Presence of IgG or IgM anti-cardiolipin antibodies
  • Presence of IgG or IgM anti-beta-2 glycoprotein I antibodies
  • At least one clinical and one laboratory criterion has to be present for a diagnosis to be made.

Management: Women are treated with low-dose aspirin (50 mg/day) and heparin (5,000 units SC twice daily) for up to 34 weeks. Unfractionated heparin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) are equally effective and safe.

 Fetal loss in APLA is due to fetal hypoxia

Note: The new 2023 ACR/EULAR criteria is an update from the revised Sapporo criteria with clinical criteria divided into 6 domains and each metric in the clinical and laboratory value adding a weighted score. This has increased the specificity in diagnosing APS.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain, and elevated AST and ALT levels, one day after undergoing emergency abdominal aortic aneurysm repair. When his right upper quadrant is palpated he winces in pain. The incision is healthy and has a serous discharge. USG reveals no abnormal fluid collection. What is the likely etiology of his pain?
questions.solution:
This patient has developed abdominal pain and elevations in his AST and ALT levels, 1 day after an emergency abdominal aneurysm repair. The likely diagnosis is shock liver due to ischemic necrosis secondary to hypotension due to exsanguination.

Perioperative hypotension is also a known complication of the surgery. 

Ischemic hepatitis, known by different terms such as ischemic hepatopathy, hypoxic hepatitis, shock liver, or acute cardiogenic liver injury, is a condition that arises from a sudden decrease in cardiac output caused by acute myocardial infarction, arrhythmia, or septic or hemorrhagic shock. Typically, it occurs in patients with passive congestion of the liver. 

The presence or observation of clinical hypotension may be lacking or not documented. In some cases, the triggering event is arterial hypoxemia related to respiratory failure, sleep apnea, severe anaemia, heat stroke, carbon monoxide poisoning, cocaine usage, or bacterial endocarditis. Administration of statin medication before hospital admission has the potential to confer protection against the occurrence of ischemic hepatitis.

Elevations in blood alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin levels are typically of a modest nature; nevertheless, the presence of jaundice is indicative of more unfavourable outcomes. The prolongation of prothrombin time may lead to the development of encephalopathy or hepatopulmonary syndrome. The mortality rate associated with the underlying disease is notably elevated, especially among patients undergoing vasopressor therapy or experiencing septic shock, acute kidney disease, or coagulopathy. However, in patients who successfully recover, the levels of aminotransferase return to their normal state rapidly, typically within a week, which stands in contrast to the prolonged normalization period observed in cases of viral hepatitis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man developed severe pain abdomen and fever 3 days after undergoing surgery for bowel perforation. There is no dehiscence or discharge from the sutured wound seen. The intra-abdominal pressure was measured to be 25mm Hg. Which of the following physiological changes will not be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario with an intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) 20 mm Hg or greater is suggestive of an abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS). It is associated with an increased central venous pressure.

The normal IAP is 5-7 mmHg. When the IAP is > 12 mmHg, it is termed intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH). ACS develops when IAP is 20 mmHg or greater, with or without abdominal perfusion pressure less than 50 mm Hg it is associated with failure of one or more organ systems.

Diagnosis is made by measuring IAP using a urinary bladder (Foley catheter) or gastric catheter. CT scan, abdominal perfusion pressure and renal filtration gradient are some of the tests done to check organ dysfunction.

The primary goal of management is to reduce the IAP. So rapid decompression is done by opening the abdomen and performing a temporary closure of the abdominal wall using a mesh or a plastic bag (Bogota bag). After the resuscitation and management of the specific causes, a definite closure of the abdomen can be done by vacuum-assisted closure (VAC), split-skin graft, or prosthetic mesh.

Related Pearl: Physiological Consequences of Increased Intra-abdominal Pressure

Decreased :

  • Cardiac output
  • Venous return
  • Visceral blood ﬂow
  • Renal blood ﬂow
  • Glomerular filtration

Increased :

  • Cardiac rate
  • Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
  • Peak inspiratory pressure
  • Central venous pressure
  • Intrapleural pressure
  • Systemic vascular resistance

questions.text: You are in the casualty observing your resident perform a test on a road traffic accident patient with acute abdominal pain. The patient winces in pain as the resident releases his hand after palpating his abdomen. What is the likely course for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with tenderness on releasing the hand rather than on applying pressure has rebound tenderness. This sign is referred to as Blumberg's sign. This is an indication that the patient has peritoneal irritation, likely secondary to a hollow viscus perforation. He will most likely need an emergency laparotomy after a preliminary FAST scan.

Rebound tenderness is an indicator of peritoneal irritation and the most common cause of this in the case of a road traffic accident would be a hollow viscus perforation. Such patients are only evaluated with a FAST scan as their vitals will be unstable requiring emergent surgery. If the vitals are stable, a CT scan of the abdomen can be done to find the site of perforation. 

Other options:

Option A: Spontaneous recovery after a hollow viscous perforation is unlikely, almost all patients require emergent surgery.

Option C: IV antibiotics are used to treat non-traumatic peritonitis, but if there is a history of trauma, a hollow viscus perforation should be strongly suspected.

Option D: While this patient might need a blood transfusion for unstable vitals, surgery will still be the main management.

Related Pearl: Abdominal examination signs

Sign Explanation Diagnosis

Bassler sign Sharp pain created by compressing appendix between the abdominal wall and iliacus Chronic appendicitis
Ten Horn sign Pain caused by gentle traction of right testicle Acute appendicitis
Blumberg's sign Transient abdominal wall rebound tenderness Peritoneal inflammation
Chandelier sign Extreme lower abdominal pain with movement of the cervix Pelvic inflammatory disease
Courvoisier's sign Palpable gallbladder in presence of painless jaundice Periampullary tumor
Cruveilhier sign Varicose veins at the umbilicus (caput-medusae) Portal hypertension
Fothergill's sign Abdominal wall mass that does not cross the midline and remains palpable when rectus contracted  Rectus muscle hematomas

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty 2 days after a high-speed car collision due to increasing abdominal pain and vomiting. On examination, he has a bruise on his abdomen that corresponds to the car seat belt. Below is his CT scan with contrast. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient following a car collision and bruises corresponding to the car seat belt has suffered a contusion of the abdomen. The CT scan shows contrast enhancement in the wall of the duodenum indicating a duodenal hematoma. This can cause pain and partial gastric construction, thus explaining his symptoms. 

Duodenal hematoma occurs after high-speed collisions which cause blunt impact on the abdomen. This leads to a compression of the duodenum against the vertebrae and leads to an injury, allowing for a slow bleed and hematoma formation.

These patients are usually managed conservatively by nasogastric decompression and IV fluids till the hematoma resolves on its own. If the hematoma is huge or it ruptures, then surgical management will be required. 

Other options:

Option B: An intraperitoneal bladder leak can lead to chemical peritonitis and a more toxic presentation. However, the CT scan showing blood in the duodenal wall makes a duodenal hematoma more likely.

Option C: Pancreatitis would present with abdominal pain radiating towards the back, and vomiting. However, the CT scan showing blood in the duodenal wall makes a duodenal hematoma more likely.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought with complaints of abdominal pain. Physical examination shows a mass in the left upper quadrant. Laboratory tests show a Hb of 6mg/dl and glucose 70mg/dl. 3 months ago his Hb was 12mg/dl. He has a past history of recurrent painful swellings of his fingers. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child presented with complaints of abdominal pain with a mass in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen. He also has a rapid reduction in serum Hb concentration (12 to 6mg/dl). This combined with a history of recurrent painful finger swelling likely indicates dactylitis secondary to sickle cell disease. This patient has developed a splenic sequestration crisis, a feared complication of sickle cell disease. 

Splenic sequestration occurs when areas of sickled cells in red pulp obstruct a major vein, leading to a propagation effect with further sickling and reduced oxygen tension. As more and more RBCs get trapped in the spleen, it can lead to massive splenomegaly. This is usually triggered by underlying conditions like infections, or acute hypoxia. This condition is usually seen in individuals below the age of 5 as patients older than this usually have auto-infarcted their spleen.

It presents as abrupt pallor, abdominal pain and distention. 

Patients are usually diagnosed clinically, but other causes of anemias should be ruled out first. CT abdomen with contrast can be done if necessary.

Treatment:

  • Rapid blood transfusion to correct the hypovolemia. This corrects the hypoxia and releases the trapped RBCs.
  • Splenic size should be monitored for reduction in size.

questions.text: The following abdominal x-ray finding is noted in a 40-year-old male patient with a history of peptic ulcer disease. Which of the following is unlikely to be observed on clinical examination of the patient?

choices.text: Patient twisting and turning in pain
Pain referred to the shoulder tip

questions.solution:
The x-ray showing free air under the diaphragm in a patient with an underlying history of peptic ulcer disease is indicative of peptic ulcer perforation. The patient is likely to be seen lying still with minimal movements rather twisting and turning in pain as movement aggravates pain in peritonism.

The classical description of a patient with a perforated peptic ulcer is described in three stages:

  • Stage of peritonism: Initial 6 hours - patient presents with an acute burning epigastric pain with or without vomiting. Leakage of gastric acid into the peritoneal cavity causes diaphragmatic irritation which may lead to pain referred to the shoulder tip (Option D) and tracking of fluid in the right para-colic gutter may lead to right iliac fossa pain. Abdominal guarding with diminished abdominal movements on respiration is noted and the patient avoids movement to prevent pain. Tachycardia (Option B) is noted but pyrexia does not set in.
  • Stage of reaction: the symptoms temporarily subside due to the dilution of the exudate in the peritoneal cavity but abdominal rigidity remains (Option A).
  • Stage of diffuse peritonitis: sunken face, hollow cheeks, dry mucous membranes (facies hippocratica) with fever, tachycardia, low volume pulse and increasing abdominal distension.

Initial management includes intravenous (IV) fluid therapy, cessation of oral intake, and administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics. Perforation is an indication for surgical exploration. Perforations less than 1 cm can be closed primarily with an omental patch repair, while larger perforations may require a distal gastrectomy with a roux-en-y reconstruction. Patients require prolonged PPI therapy postoperatively.

questions.text: An elderly male presents with a 2-day history of abdominal pain. He denies any trauma. On examination, there is a tender mass in the left iliac area. The pain increases and the mass becomes more prominent on abdominal tensing. He has a history of deep vein thrombosis for which he takes anticoagulants. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient presenting with a 2-day history of abdominal pain and a mass with concurrent use of anticoagulation has most likely developed a rectus sheath hematoma. 

A rectus sheath hematoma occurs due to the accumulation of blood in the rectus sheath. This is usually spontaneous in old patients due to weakness of the rectus sheath. Anticoagulants further increase the risk of a bleed. Other risk factors include trauma, previous surgery, abdominal strain, coughing , pregnancy etc. It usually occurs in the lower abdomen. 

It presents as a painful lower abdominal mass and does not cross the midline. Imaging is done to confirm the diagnosis but is not required unless it's an expanding hematoma. 

Treatment: Conservative management is preferred, only if there's no hemodynamic compromise. If this fails, surgery will be required. 

Other options:

Option B: Divarication of recti is the thinning of the linea alba in the epigastrium with protrusion of the abdominal wall with prominent edges of both recti. It becomes prominent on lifting the head from the bed. No treatment is required in the divarication of recti.

Option C: Spigelian hernias arise from a defect in the Spigelian fascia, which is the aponeurosis of the transversus abdominis muscle. The fascia extends between the transversus muscle and the lateral border of the rectus sheath from the costal margin to the groin, where it blends into the conjoint tendon. This patients lesion is not consistent with the location of a spigelian hernia. 

Option D: In adults, umbilical hernias are typically acquired, with a greater incidence observed among females. Various factors, including pregnancy, obesity, and liver illness accompanied by cirrhosis and ascites, can lead to the elongation and attenuation of the midline raphe (linea alba), hence increasing the likelihood of reoccurrence of the umbilical defect.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old male complains of abdominal distension and pain 2 days. He is diagnosed with colonic pseudobstruction. Which of the following are risk factors associated with the development of this disease?
  1. Psychiatric illnesses
  2. Recent surgery
  3. Prolonged fasting
  4. Opioid use
  5. Adhesions
questions.solution:
Prolonged fasting and adhesions are not risk factors for the development of a colonic pseudo-obstruction.

Psuedo-obstruction can present in acute or chronic forms. The acute form is seen in medically ill patients and affects the colon. The chronic form affects other parts of the gastrointestinal tract and presents with recurring subacute and partial intestinal obstruction.

Risk factors for developing pseudo obstructions are usually conditions that usually cause a decrease in colonic motility. Psychiatric conditions are a risk factor due to the medications used to treat them having anticholinergic side effects which can precipitate this condition after prolonged use. Recent surgery and opioid use also leads to paralytic ileus and a reduction in motility respectively.

Diagnosis is by abdominal X-rays which show distended colon with the right and transverse segment of colon affected majorly. A transition point is often present, usually at or near the splenic flexure.

The most useful investigation is a water-soluble enema. Contrast enema differentiates mechanical obstruction and pseudo-obstruction

Initial treatment is by nasogastric decompression, fluid deficit replacement, and electrolyte abnormality correction. Medications that inhibit bowel movements should be discontinued. Most patients improve with this regimen and conservative treatment with serial X-rays or USG.

questions.text:
Match the type of acute abdominal pain with the most likely diagnosis
1)Radiating to the back a) Appendicitis
2)Periumbilical b) Pancreatitis
3)Left lower quadrant c) Diverticulitis
4)Diffuse abdominal pain d) Renal calculus
5)Colicky pain e) Mesenteric atherosclerosis
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-b, 2-a, 3-c, 4-e, 5-d

Diagnosis of many conditions can be aided by the typical pattern of abdominal pain.

Pancreatitis causes abdominal pain that radiates to the back as it is a retroperitoneal organ. 

Appendicitis initially causes periumbilical pain as the pain is transmitted along the T10 dermatome before getting localized to McBurney's point.

Diverticulitis occurs due to an inflammation of a diverticulum in the large bowel, and these diverticula are usually in the left descending colon. Hence there is left lower quadrant pain.

Diffuse abdominal pain is seen in mesenteric atherosclerosis. It is also termed angina of the abdomen and occurs due to a supply-demand mismatch leading to pain in the abdomen diffusely. It classically presents as pain out of proportion to the findings.

Colicky pain is seen in the passage of renal stones through the ureter in a loin-to-groin distribution.

questions.text: A child is brought to you with abdominal pain after he ingested something. Ingestion of which of the following objects requires urgent intervention?
questions.solution:
Out of the given options, ingestion of magnets requires urgent intervention, as there is no way to ascertain how many the child has ingested. They can stick to each other through different loops and can cause pressure necrosis of the bowel wall and perforation. Thus they need urgent intervention to prevent complications. 

All the other options are examples of inert objects that are usually allowed to be excreted via stools if they have passed into the stomach as they will have cleared the narrowest part of the GI tract. 

Foreign bodies commonly ingested by children are coins, disk batteries, and small toy items. In adults, it is usually a food bolus (mostly meat) that gets lodged. Initial symptoms are choking, gagging, and coughing followed by excessive salivation, dysphagia, food refusal, vomiting, or pain in the neck and throat. 

Imaging with chest and abdominal X-rays should be performed in AP and lateral positions. Chest CT should always be performed if oesophageal perforation is suspected.

Endoscopic removal of the esophageal foreign body is the procedure of choice. It should be performed:

  • Immediately in esophageal obstruction, disk batteries, and sharp pointed objects.
  • Within 12-24 hours in non-pointed objects, pointed objects in the stomach, and coins in the esophagus if they're not passed spontaeneously.
  • Non-urgent removal in objects in stomach >2.5cm in diameter, and disk battery in the stomach (up to 48h)

questions.text:
A 65-year-old lady comes to the hospital due to a 1-hour history of epigastric pain and diaphoresis. Examination shows no abdominal tenderness. Her ECG recording is shown below. Which of the following concomitant findings would be likely in this patient?

JVP- Jugular venous pressure
questions.solution:
This patient with epigastric abdominal pain and ECG with ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF is suggestive of an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Raised JVP is seen in an inferior wall MI as it causes build-up of blood in the right heart and thus transmits back pressure to the right jugular vein.

Myocardial infarction (MI) occurs when there is an occlusion of one or more arteries supplying the heart. This leads to an imbalance between myocardial oxygen demand and supply, leading to myocardial ischemia and death. An inferior wall MI can present atypically with abdominal pain in women and diabetics, so any patient with a high degree of suspicion for an MI presenting with epigastric pain should be evaluated for it via ECG. 

Treatment of MI primarily involves control of discomfort, fibrinolysis, and reperfusion therapy. Reperfusion therapy includes both PCI and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). 

In PCI, a stent or balloon is inserted into the occluded artery to restore blood flow. It is done under local anaesthesia and mild sedation. In CABG, a vessel is grafted from a different part of the body and is used to restore blood flow by bypassing the occlusion. It is a surgical procedure. CABG is generally preferred for severe left main and three-vessel disease. 

Reperfusion therapy should be done as soon as possible, within a few hours of the onset of symptoms. It has better short-term and long-term outcomes when compared to fibrinolysis alone. 

Other options: 

Options A and D: Diffuse abdominal tenderness is seen in a perforated peptic ulcer and hematochezia can be expected in a case of a bleeding peptic ulcer. This patients patient's ECG shows ST elevations in leads II, III and aVF, indicating an inferior wall MI. 

Option C: Facial flushing can be seen in superior sulcus tumours and carcinoid syndromes, but the ECG findings here make MI more likely.

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

Related Pearl: Indications for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG)

Class I indications for CABG from the American College of Cardiology(ACC) and American Heart Association(AHA).

  • Left main disease
  • Three-vessel disease with or without proximal LAD disease
  • Two vessel disease with proximal LAD disease
  • Survivors of sudden cardiac death with presumed ischemia-mediated VT  

Other indications for CABG include the following:

  • Disabling angina
  • Ongoing ischemia in the setting of a non–ST-segment elevation (MI) that is unresponsive to medical therapy
  • Poor LV function but with viable, nonfunctioning myocardium above the anatomic defect that can be revascularized

questions.text: An air conditioner technician presents with acute abdominal pain and diarrhea. He also has a dry cough and malaise. Serum electrolytes show hyponatremia. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the electrolyte studies showing hyponatremia point toward the diagnosis of Legionnaire's disease. This is caused by Legionella pneumophila.

They are found in lakes, streams, and other water bodies. Infection is mostly spread by inhalation of the bacteria from aerosols produced by contaminated air conditioners, humidifiers, nebulizers, etc.

It presents mostly asymptomatically under the age of 55 years. Infection is usually severe in immunocompromised patients. It may present as a severe, rapidly progressive disease with high fever, chills, hypoxia, diarrhea, and delirium. On chest x-ray, patchy, often multilobar consolidation is seen. Pleural effusion may also occur. Hyponatremia is a feature typical of this infection too. 

A milder form of a clinical syndrome known as Pontiac fever, which is usually self-limiting and only has mild symptoms of fever, myalgia, and headache.

Microscopy of the sputum samples shows numerous leucocytes without any organism. Gram staining of the sterile sites like pleural fluid and lung tissues show faint gram-negative bacilli. They require a counterstain of basic fuschin as safranin stains the bacteria very poorly. They are a group of fastidious, aerobic gram-negative bacteria. They can be grown on a buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) agar.

Diagnosis is established with the help of direct fluorescent antibody tests and BCYE culture specimens. Urine antigen tests and molecular assays may also be used.

The below image shows the Direct Fluorescent Antibody Test.

As L. pneumophila are intracellular pathogens, antibiotics that reach high intracellular concentrations must be used. Macrolides and quinolones are the antibiotics of choice and are effective as monotherapy. Alternatively, agents like doxycycline may also be used. B-lactams, monobactams, and aminoglycosides are not considered to be effective. The total duration of therapy is 10-14 days for immunocompetent hosts and up to 3 weeks for immunosuppressed patients.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought with complaints of abdominal pain. He has not passed stools in 2 days. His mother informs that his last stool was pebble-shaped and hard. He recently started preschool. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child presenting with complaints of abdominal pain and no stool passage since 2 days and a history of starting preschool recently likely has functional constipation. 

Functional constipation is a clinical diagnosis. It occurs when a child starts a new activity like toilet training or starting preschool which requires withholding behavior. This is still a social stressor for them and can lead to maladaptive responses leading to constipation. 

The condition is benign and usually resolves on its own. Disimpaction can be done in severe cases but otherwise the mode of treatment is just with laxatives and behavioral approaches.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with colicky abdominal pain, arthralgia, and purpuric rash on the thighs after an upper respiratory tract infection. Which of the additional features can be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of Henoch Schonlein purpura(HSP). The additional clinical feature that can be seen is glomerulonephritis in severe cases of HSP.

Henoch schonlein purpura is also known as IgA vasculitis.

It is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by palpable purpura, arthralgias, gastrointestinal signs and symptoms, and glomerulonephritis.

Gastrointestinal manifestations are colicky abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, and passage of blood in stools.

It is more commonly seen in children aged 4-7 years. Some of the factors that trigger the development of HSP include upper respiratory infections, drugs, foods, insect bites, and immunizations.

Skin biopsy is used to confirm the diagnosis by demonstrating the leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA and C3 deposition by immunofluorescence.

Henoch Schonlein purpura has an excellent prognosis. Patients with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis are treated with glucocorticoids.

Other options:

Option A: Bechet's syndrome is characterized by recurrent genital ulcers, oral ulcers, skin lesions, eye lesions, or a positive pathergy test. Some of the patients have HLA B*51 positivity. Oral ulcers are usually the first manifestation of the disease.

Option B: Microscopic polyangiitis affects small and medium-sized arteries with a predilection to involve the capillaries and venules Glomerulonephritis and hemoptysis due to alveolar hemorrhage can also occur. 

Option C: Thrombocytopenia is not a feature of Henoch Schonlein purpura. Laboratory findings of HSP include mild leukocytosis, normal platelet count, and eosinophilia.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presenting with acute abdominal pain had previously been diagnosed with uterine fibroids. Which of the following complications is most unlikely to have occurred here?
questions.solution:
Hyaline degeneration of fibroids is unlikely here as it is usually painless and presents as an abdominal mass causing distension and heaviness.

Acute pain in fibroids is seen in the case of: 

  • Fibroid torsion
  • Hemorrhage into the fibroid
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change - seen in postmenopausal women.

questions.text:
A patient presenting with acute abdomen was found to have elevated serum amylase levels. Which of the following should be part of your differential diagnosis?
  1. Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  2. Abdominal aortic aneurysm
  3. Cholecystitis
  4. Diabetic ketoacidosis
  5. Intestinal obstruction
questions.solution:
All the above conditions should be part of the differential diagnosis in patients with acute abdominal pain and elevated serum amylase levels.

Conditions associated with elevated serum amylase levels:

  • Burns
  • Pregnancy
  • Pancreatitis
  • Cholecystitis
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Aortic aneurysm
  • Renal failure
  • Renal transplantation
  • Chronic liver disease
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Drugs like morphine
  • Salivary gland involvement: mumps, calculus, maxillofacial surgery
  • Tumors of the lungs, esophagus, breast, or ovary (LEBO)

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with complaints of abdominal pain, bloody stools, and generalized muscle pain. Her blood pressure is 200/110 mmHg. She was diagnosed with polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). What are the histopathological changes seen on biopsy?

choices.text: Fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina
Adventitial mononuclear infiltrates and intimal hyperplasia
Segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation with aneurysms
Segmental fibrinoid necrosis of the capillaries

questions.solution:
The histopathological changes seen on biopsy in PAN are segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation with aneurysms.

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a systemic vasculitis affecting the small-medium-sized arteries. PAN characteristically involves the renal and visceral vessels and spares the pulmonary vasculature. There is no association with antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA), but a third of the patients are positive for hepatitis B. 

The commonly involved organs in PAN are the kidney, heart, liver, and gastrointestinal tract. Inadequate perfusion results in ischemia, ulcerations, infarcts, or hemorrhage.

It classically presents as rapidly accelerating hypertension, acute abdominal pain, bloody stools, diffuse myalgias, and motor peripheral neuropathy. The diagnosis is based on a biopsy showing segmental necrotizing transmural inflammation of small-medium-sized arteries with aneurysms and thrombosis of the vessels involved, as shown below.

Diagnosis can also be made by the demonstration of aneurysms of small- and medium-sized arteries in the renal, hepatic, and visceral vasculature. An angiogram showing aneurysms of renal arteries is given below.

Other options:

Option A: Fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina (black arrow) is seen in giant cell arteritis. It affects large to small-sized arteries. The involved segments have thickened intima, reduced luminal diameter, fragmented internal elastic lamina, and multinucleated giant cells (yellow arrow). Clinically, it presents after 50 years of age with headache or facial pain, most intense along the course of the superficial temporal artery, painful to palpation, and visual symptoms.

Option B: Adventitial mononuclear infiltrates and intimal hyperplasia is seen in Takayasu arteritis. It affects larger vessels. It is characterized clinically by ocular symptoms and weakened pulses in the upper extremities. Aortic root involvement causes dilation and aortic valve insufficiency.

Option D: Segmental fibrinoid necrosis of the capillaries is seen in microscopic polyangiitis (MPA). It is also known as leukocytoclastic vasculitis as only neutrophil infiltration is present. It presents as hemoptysis, hematuria and proteinuria, bowel pain or bleeding, muscle pain or weakness, and palpable cutaneous purpura, depending on the vessel and organ involved.
